encodingDesc.p: The Mixtepec-Mixtec (MIX) dictionary file contains 1137 lexical entries and related entries which represent only a fraction of the total vocabulary contents of this project. These items are continually being added from the sources in the bibliography and from spoken utterances.

editorialDecl.p: The vocabulary contents of this document are meant to be entered as a result of mining the language resource data sources from which the vocabulary was obtained. The entries in this version of the document were made manually however future versions will be made using XSLT processes that mine all transcribed, written and glossed MIX data.

cit.quote: Yo'o nantakani iin tu'un yata ña nikuu nisa'a kue nivi na ntsintee ta tsa na'a.

entry.note: In static spatial phrases it can denote an upper region of an item:

etym.seg: Mixtecan cognates and historical forms show extremely strong similarity.

sense.def: The front of (sth).
La parte delantera de (algo).

graphic.desc: The image shows the front part of the houses colored yellow.

etym.seg: active zone source profile (aka ontological knowledge/impetus) motivating the metaphor is the relative configuration of the part FACE relative to (LM) BODY. FRONT-REGION partOf BODY> FRONT-REGION partOf OBJECT
FRONT-REGION partOf BODY > ADJACENT-SPACE to FRONT-REGION OfBody
etym.note: LM must still be Body(of person or animal)

entry.note: the lemma form can be inflected to reflect: possessive (person, number, ), register, Semantic Role (eg. ..)

sense.def: Used in combination with another locational noun to refer to a transitional or border region of that item.

cit.quote: Sara ntsai yu'u yucha ka sara ntsikutanchii nuu yuu ka sara nikitsai tsi'a chikuii.

etym.seg: If the object of reference in not a human, then the sense is also metaphorical.
part of BODY → part of FRUIT

etym.note: As the face is the part of the body which interacts with the external world, the palm is the part of the hand which interacts with the external world

sense.note: this could have multiple analyses, one in which 'back' is considered to be a 'body part' term only and is metaphorically applied to other domains, the other in which

cit.quote: The house is on the bottom of the hill
I'm speaking on behalf of Pedro.
Estoy hablando de parte de Pedro.
ko'a cho'a tsini yu ña tsa'a kue Azteca ka
tsa'a ña ntsini tixikua ka lochi ra ntavi

etym.seg: Which is Metonymy (part for whole): the metal bars are a prominant part of the concept of jail thus provide a salient lexical reference point for the vocabulary.
Which is Metonymy (part for whole): the activity of working is a prominant part of the concept of town hall thus provides a salient lexical reference point for the vocabulary.

etym.note: not sure of the directionality of the metonymy: ('outside' - 'door') or ('door' - 'outside')

etym.seg: This word is derived from a compound of 'head' and 'house/building'. The use of the former represents a shift in the domain of the source term from 'head' as a direct meronym of 'body' to a meronym of 'building'. Thus the semantic profile shift is: 'TOP partOf BODY' to 'TOP partOf BUILDING'.

sense.note: Double check this. Get example from speaker.

etym.seg: This is likely the native Mixtec term for "father".

sense.usg: Also a term of respect for older males.

sense.def: brother's wife

sense.note: This description of the entry for the MIX language is from Wikipedia and is in need of editing. I include this link to show that the infrustructure exists for linking this concept to linked open data ontologies is inplace once the information is more refined.

entry.note: This description of the entry for the MIX language is from Wikipedia and is in need of editing. I include this link to show that the infrustructure exists for linking this concept to linked open data ontologies is inplace once the information is more refined. http://dbpedia.org/resource/Mixtepec_Mixtec

sense.note: This term which translates as "poor language" is dispreferred by speakers consulted as it is derrogatory. This is so particularly in contrast to the term for the Spanish language sa'an xchila which translates as "fancy language".

etym.seg: The assumption in the use of this term is that those that speak this language are poor.

cit.quote: Ika ka'an na siin siin sa'an tono sa'an xchila, portugués, francés, quechua tsi inka ka kue sa'an.
Ika ka'an na siin siin sa'an tono sa'an xchila, portugués, francés, quechua tsi inka ka kue sa'an.
Ika ka'an na siin siin sa'an tono sa'an xchila, portugués, francés, quechua tsi inka ka kue sa'an.
Ika ka'an na siin siin sa'an tono sa'an xchila, portugués, francés, quechua tsi inka ka kue sa'an.

sense.note: It is my hypothesis that the 'ti' in this lexical item is the source of: the animal-type enclitic -ti; and the presence of that segment within multiple lexical items for different animals (and insects) in the language: eg., 'tina', 'tisu'ma', "

etym.seg: In this lexical item, the language reflects the history, since there were no horses in Mexico until the arrival of the Spanish in the Mixteca (sometime in 1520), there was naturally no Mixtecan word for 'horse'. Thus it is clear that the categorical noun meaning 'animal' was used to describe the unnamed animal and this term lexicalized into the language.

sense.note: (Unsure of specific type of rattlesnake!!)
(Unsure of specific type of rattlesnake!!)
(Unsure of specific type of snake!!)
(Unsure of specific type of snake!!)
Need to get specific type of snake!!
Need to get specific type of snake!!

etym.seg: While the tones differ, the terms may still be related. As is the case for horses, pigs were introduced to Mexico by Europeans during colonization which would explain the need to create a new lexical itemin the language for these animals. I propose that this form may have come from the word for 'evil', as upon introduction to the territory, pigs were known historically to have decimated native crops which caused large-scale problems.
The use of "flower" is clearly ironic in nature.

sense.note: Not sure of specific species of scrub jay.

cit.quote: Niki'in kuili ka'nu ka ña chi'ntu tsatsi kuili luu luu ka
the big scrub jay took the nut that the little scrub jay was eating.

note.note: Not entirely certain of the specific subspecies of Thrasher, but judging from the content of the following Wikipedia article: it seems most likely that it is the Ocellated Thrasher.

sense.note: I am nearly certain this is the grey hawk. The other possibility Grey-lined Hawk is only found from southern Costa Rica to Argentina.

cit.quote: In kii ra in lakuku kunia tanta'i tsi in ncho'o, cha koo xu'in sa'i viko.

sense.note: Check is this a specific type of cricket?

sense.def: Small mosquito that doesn't make noise.
Zancudo chico que no hace ruído.

sense.note: Check if this is equaly "to give off smoke" and "to smoke (cigarettes, etc.)"

etym.note: This form likely related to the heat associated with 'innards'/'guts' as 'ini' is given with this meaning in numerous related forms of Mixtecan;

cit.quote: Ñu'u Ñcha'i ka kai tono iin tikuaa.
Kunchee ña "Polo" tsi "Hemisferio" siin siin kui.
Kunchee ña "Polo" tsi "Hemisferio" siin siin kui.

etym.note: found in expression describing relative Configurations: observed in [ʧí.kù.ʧí ŋk̬àá ʃì-nṹ ɾà ʧí.nì.nũ̀ ŋk̬àá tsà-ʔú]
[ʧí.nì.nùù] found in expression describing relative Configurations 'below' [ʧí.kù.ʧí ŋk̬àá ʃì-nṹ ɾà ʧí.nì.nũ̀ ŋk̬àá tsà.ʔú]

cit.quote: Su'a na'a ntikumi tsio tono chi Kuchi, chi Ninu, chi Kua'a tsi chi Sachi.
Cha nche'e ko tuku ña chi Kua'a inkaa nikanchii, ra chi Sachi inkaa nta'a tsi.
Cha nche'e ko tuku ña chi Kua'a inkaa nikanchii, ra chi Sachi inkaa nta'a tsi.
Saan so kavi nuu ña'a tee ntui ra koi yee, cha nania "eje".
Ña tsan'cha ma'i sava ntaa Ñu'u Ncha'i tsio kua'a tsi tsio sachi nania "Meridiano".
Cha yee oko utsi iin ñuu ka'nu nania "estado" nuu Nko'yo.
Nuu Ñu'u Ncha'i kantu'u nuu Ñuu Ntua ita'in tsi sava ka kue Ñuu na'nu tsio tsinu nikanchii.
Yee utsi uni ñuu nuu Ñu'u chi Ninu.
Yee iñu "continente" nania: África, América, Antártida, Asia, Europa tsi Oceanía .
Yee utsi uni ñuu nuu Ñu'u chi Ninu.
Yee utsi uni ñuu nuu Ñu'u chi Ninu.
Cha yee oko utsi iin ñuu ka'nu nania "estado" nuu Nko'yo.
An there are 31 large territories/lands called "states" in Mexico
Y hay 31 territorios grandes llamados "estados" en Mexico.
Nuu Ñu'u Ncha'i kantu'u nuu Ñuu Ntua ita'in tsi sava ka kue Ñuu na'nu tsio tsinu nikanchii.

form.orth: Heroica Ciudad de Huajuapan de León
Heroica Ciudad de Huajuapan de León

etym.seg: named for a prominant landmark, feature of the city.

etym.note: this lexical concept inherantly entails relative configuration of flat landscape (plain) with regards to hills or mountains

cit.quote: Numa ña yutu ka ntsinu mancha vikó
The trunk of the tree extended all the way to the clouds.
El tronco del arbol extendió hasta las nubes.

sense.note: this is the form for 'tree' given by speaker JS, however speaker TS considers this to refer to a tree that is no loger alive or that is used for firewood

entry.note: this is the form for 'tree' given by speaker JS, however speaker TS considers this to refer to a tree that is no loger alive or that is used for firewood

sense.def: In kui'i ntikuaan kui ra titsia inkaa in tintuu.

etym.seg: The motivating source of the metaphor is the similarity in shape and color between the source concept 'bean' and the target object 'kidney'. The directionality of 'bean' → 'kidney' is assumed based on the fact that the later is a basic food staple of Mixtec people and that according to the theory of embodiment, we would expect polysemy to proliferate in the direction of: more basic/prominent → less basic/prominent. While body parts are amongst the most prominent in creating polysemies and new terms, the kidney is an internal organ and thus it is likely a less prominant concept in the embodied experience of the early Mixtecan speakers whose usage gave rise to this lexicalization.

form.note: I am assuming that the use of the voiced alveolar stop by Pike and Ibachis consistant with the pattern of those authors missing the prenasalization that is confirmed present on many other lexical items.

sense.def: indefinite article
artículo indefinido

etym.note: It is my hypothesis that the process of tone change would have happened simultaneously with that of apokope

cit.quote: Kunchee ñasuii ka ña inkai ma'i
Look at the little boy that's in the middle.
Mira el niñito que está en el medio.

sense.def: Flat grindstone tool used for processing grains and seeds, especially corn in food preparation.

sense.note: Ask about usage, get other forms to make sure "ku-" is permantly part of form.

entry.note: in representing Time as a 2-dimentional spectrum; eg: (Past to Future); Present can be represented as a single point exactly in the middle;

cit.quote: And it takes one year to orbit.
Y hace un año para girarse alrededor
Yoo ichi kuu febreru mancha avri.
Spring goes from Feruary till April
Yoo savi kuu mayo mancha septiembre.
The Rain season is from May to September.
La estación de lluvia dura de mayo hasta septiembre.

etym.seg: Metonomy: rain is the prominent weather feature of season.

cit.quote: Yoo vitsi kuu octubre mancha enero.
Cha nuu ntsini kue nivi ña ma kuu sa’a na ña cha’ncha yutu ka
And then the people realized that they would not be able to chop down the tree.
Y entonces la gente se daron cuento de que ello no irían reusir a cortar el árbol.

cit.note: this is the same kà that appears in the locative copula ŋk̬àà..
this is the same kà that appears in the locative copula ŋk̬àà..

cit.quote: Tu'un yata ñaña'a kua'in tsi inka chaa

etym.seg: Active zone of source profile (aka ontological knowledge/impetus) motivating the metaphor is QUANTITY. The domain mapping directionality of the sense change is: QUANTITY of space (SIZE or DISTANCE) → QUANTITY of TIME. The domain shift is thus: space → TIME. This directionality is predictable as it follows the pattern of: CONCRETE → ABSTRACT; and of which, the formost is space → TIME.

cit.quote: The clouds are very high up (in the sky).
Las nubes estan muy altos (en el cielo).

cit.note: Not sure how to classify this, since 'wholeness' is inherantly in the profile of the number one.

cit.quote: Su'a na'a ntikumi tsio tono chi Kuchi, chi Ninu, chi Kua'a tsi chi Sachi.

sense.def: repetitive prefix

sense.note: no known central sense

cit.quote: Sara in chaa ntuku tutú ntsini so’o ra ña nta’ia ta ntsa’an ra ntsanche’e re nuu ñantu’i.
Then a man looking for wood heard the crying and came up to and saw where the boy was sitting down.
Y un hombre buscando madera oyó los gritos y vinó y vió dónde el niño se estaba sentado.
Ntakani na nuu ña ntivi karru ku.
Someone told me that your car broke down.
Alguien me dijó que tu coche se estropeó.

cit.quote: ntsika yu yavi takua kuntivi'i nuu kuartu ka.
I asked for the key so that I could get into the room.

form.note: Pike and Ibach have a pattern of transcribing words that begin with a prenasalized stop (nt- and nk-) without the nasals. Even without having observed this item personally, I am assuming that the pattern is consistant and that the form should be a prenasalized alveolar stop.

sense.note: Get info on whether this is used in the domain of cooking or other..
